Hyper-Democracy

Why force creates extreme arguments and why there are better options.

Daniel Goldman
Mar 4

Byrne Hobart makes some interesting points in his article on political disagreement and why people take extreme positions. To me, one of the most important lines in the entire article is as follows: “…every enforced law establishes an Overton Window of what’s acceptable.”

First, a little background. Unfortunately Hobart doesn’t go into detail about what the Overton window is. Simply put, it’s the collection of ideas which are considered acceptable by a given society. The window can be combined a classification of ideas from most accepted to least accepted: policy, popular, sensible, acceptable, radical, and unthinkable (Wiki).

It’s true that, if we consider acceptance as a tug of war between extremes, it can make sense to maintain the extreme position in debate, as doing otherwise would allow the more extreme position to win out. But so long as all parties involved maintain the extreme position and counter the alternative extreme position, the Overton window is maintained. But why is it so important to maintain the Overton window? The answer comes down to a fundamental flaw in democracy.

This remainder of this discussion is based on a previous discussion that I wrote on Politicoid. Expanding on the original idea of the article, we can see that when force is involved, maintaining the Overton window is very important, even for seemingly mundane issues.

Jonathan McIntosh made an interesting comment wanting to replace markets with a “democratic” process. But markets are more democratic than democracy. It was quite some time ago that McIntosh made this remark, but I do not follow him and I first saw the comment recently. Here’s his actual quote.

Voter Turnout

Now, how can something be more democratic than a democracy? The key is actually found in Mcintosh’s comment. He uses the word “participatory.” How do you participate in the planning process in a democracy? You vote. If you don’t vote, you do not participate. Of course, we know that not everyone votes. The 2012 presidential election had a 54.87% voter turnout rate. Elections for other officials have even lower voter turnouts. Democracies are only democratic when there is 100% voter turnout and that rarely happens.

Inaction as Participation

Now let’s compare this scenario to natural market dynamics. In a natural market, inaction is participation. We see this form of voting all the time. How do you get a business to change its policies? You don’t do it by casting a ballot. You do it by not shopping at that business. In many ways inaction is even more powerful than action when it comes to natural market dynamics. The fact that inaction is participation, you end up with 100% voter participation every time.

Let’s take Black Friday sales. Yes; they are still quite popular and sadly quite dangerous, but more and more people are choosing to shop online rather than in physical establishments. This is actually beneficial for box stores. Online orders are far less expensive. It doesn’t take a cashier or any sales associates.

Now, of course, the United States is a democratic republic rather than a democracy so it is even less democratic than a true democracy, but the comment was merely about finding a “democratic participatory planning process.” So it is clear that this is exactly what the set of natural market dynamics happens to be.

Government Influence

Government can manipulate the vote. This is true both in democracies and in markets. Natural markets are one thing, but we have to be careful because we do not live in a natural market. Going back to the box stores for a second, it’s true that choosing not to shop at Walmart et al is a vote against Walmart, but the government does a lot of the voting for us by taking resources away from us and giving them to domesticated businesses. Still, this is not an issue with the market. It is an issue with domestication of market agents.

Sushi or Pizza: Agreeing to Disagree?

Perhaps the best analogy to help explain the issue with politics is my sushi or pizza analogy, and it’s the analogy that I used in response to Hobart’s commentary.

This is the crux of the issue. When a decision is voluntary, there is less of a benefit to being extreme. But when it becomes mandated through force, even deciding what to eat can become extreme.
Take for instance a group of people, who once a week go out for dinner. Each week, they vote on what to eat. And no matter what, each member has to pay in, even if they don’t want to go. They also cannot stop going.
A person who doesn’t like sushi is now going to “fight to the death” to avoid going for sushi. A person who cannot eat gluten is going to potentially literally fight to the death to avoid getting pizza.

When something is no longer voluntary, but determined by another person or group, even if it is the majority, peaceful disagreement becomes nearly impossible. Even though a lot of people say that we should simply “agree to disagree” we cannot, because those who take an active position still wish to use force to have others submit to their viewpoints. That’s not agreeing to disagree. And thus, we must take extreme positions, well beyond the Overton window, in order to protect the our own positions, which would themselves fall within the window.

Meanwhile, voluntary associations reduce the need for extreme positions, because we can vote, not only through action, but also through inaction. Thus markets, and other voluntary activities, are forms of hyper-democratic decision making processes. I do expect hyper-democracy to be the primary method of decision making in the future, especially with the rise of blockchain.
